Variation Example: A man & his wife make a wager: Whoever speaks first must do certain work (close the door, wash the dishes, feed the animals, etc.). Strangers (robbers) enter their house & take or abuse their belongings (believe the couple are dead & share their estate). A man rapes the woman (a woman tries to rape the man). The husband (wife) protests (becomes jealous), cries out, & thus loses the wager.

A husband & wife quarrel & do not speak to each other for a whole day. Before they go to sleep, the husband puts a board (pillow) in the middle of the bed between them. In the night the man sneezes. “God help you”, says his wife from the other side of the bed. “Do you really mean that?” asks the man. “Yes”, says the wife. The man replies, “Then take away the board!”
A man criticizes his wife for talking too much & so she stops speaking at all. After two days he starts searching everywhere & she asks him what he is looking for. He answers, “Your tongue”.
This misc. type comprises various tales dealing with married couples who quarrel or who play tricks on each other.

A woman wants to poison her husband. The pharmacist gives her herbs instead of the poison that she re-quests. He tells her husband that she had asked him for poison. The wife sprinkles the herbs on a bowl of soup & serves it to her husband. He pretends to die. The wife puts a rope through a hole leading upstairs & ties it around the man’s neck. She goes upstairs & tries to pull him up, but he unties himself & ties the rope to his workbench. She uses the rope to pull it up & fastens the rope. Then she calls out the window for help, saying that her husband hanged himself. The wife is tried & convicted.

A man (farmer, baker, barber) suffers at the hands of his obstinate wife. He complains to the clergyman (his master), who tells him that each man has his own cross to bear (carry). The man goes home, lifts his wife on his back, & carries her. After this, she becomes more tractable.

Classifications: The Devil Guards the Wife's Chastity
Variation Example: A man who is exasperated with his quarrelsome wife exclaims, “May the devil take you!”. The devil takes this command seriously, defends her chastity, & carries off her would-be lovers (even in hell, she is unmanageable). Finally he gives up & sends her back to her husband, saying it would be easier to herd wild horses (wild pigs).

A rich man (merchant) gives his wife a (two) parrot so that she will have company while he is away. She falls in love during her husband’s absence (and kills the parrot [one of the parrots] because he will not let her visit her lover). Every time she wants to go to her lover, the (other) parrot holds her back by telling a long story (he tells seven stories in seven days), until her husband returns.

The devil wants to separate a man & his wife (because he is jealous of their happiness). He asks an old woman to help him (promises her a pair of shoes). The old woman tells the wife that her husband is unfaithful to her, & that in order to make him love her again, she should cut three hairs from his beard when he is asleep. The old woman tells the husband that his wife intends to kill him. When the wife comes at night with a knife to cut the hairs, he beats (kills) her.

A woman whose husband is ill wishes that death would take her (instead of him). When death (a neighbor dressed as death, death in the form of a bird [owl, crow, goose, chicken]) comes (sent by the husband to test his wife) to take the wife, she points instead to her husband.
An old man feels relieved by the death of his wife. He says to death, “You have caused me a lot of trouble, but now you will not do so any more”.

A dead woman (man) is being carried to her grave. One of the coffin bearers bumps into a wall & the shock brings the dead woman back to life. She dies again the following year. Her husband tells the coffin bearers to be careful how they go, so the same mistake will not happen again.

Two farmers are discussing the weather. “This weather is good for growing”, says one. “Tonight everything will spring out of the ground”. “I hope not”, says the other, “My wife (two, three wives) is buried there”.

Classifications: The Man Hidden under the Bed
Variation Example: This misc. type comprises different anecdotes dealing with adultery, some of which are not clearly described in the regional type catalogues: The lover hides under the bed when the husband comes home. In most cases the lover misunderstands something that the husband says & betrays himself by his spontaneous reply.

Classifications: The Lord Above the Lord Below
Variation Example: While her husband is away, a wife is visited by two of her lovers. When her husband suddenly comes home, one hides on the roof & the second hides under the bed. The wife distracts her husband with foolish phrases & accuses him of having wasted all his money on drink. He defends himself & says, “The Lord above will pay for everything”. The man on the roof says he will pay for half, but the man under the bed (below) must pay for the other half. In Italian variants the meeting of the adulterous wife & her lover is interrupted by a fool who follows his dog into the house. He embraces the woman & hides from the husband in the hearth. When the husband starts a fire, the fool defends himself, “I had your wife only once, but the man under the bed has her a thousand times”. The husband kills the lover & gives the fool money to keep quiet.
A neighbor (miller) tells a husband about his wife’s unfaithfulness, & they surprise her with her lover. She assumes the role of judge & sentences all three men to be punished.

Classifications: I Can See the Whole World!
Variation Example: A farmer (herdsman) who has lost an animal (horse, donkey, cow) climbs a tree to look for it (looks for it under a bed). He accidentally witnesses a couple embracing. Af-ter their intercourse (on seeing the woman’s naked body) the lover (man or woman) says metaphorically, “I have seen the whole world!” (some similar expression). The farmer asks the man if he has seen his lost animal. The couple are frightened & run away so fast that they leave some article behind which the farmer takes. (The adulterer gives the farm-er money to keep quiet. If the couple are married, they beat the farmer.)

Lovers are consorting under a tree (in a barn). The woman worries about the consequences & asks her lover, “Who will provide for the child?” He answers, “The Lord above us will take care of it”. A man hiding in the tree (on the roof) says, “I certainly will not!”

A husband wants to sound out his wife. He tells her that every wife should have a lover so that other men will respect her husband (because otherwise her husband will not respect her). The wife admits that she does have a lover.

A married couple frequently engage in adultery. The wife puts a pea in a jar each time, & the husband puts a marble in a bag. After a while they compare numbers, & the husband sees that the wife has fewer peas than he has marbles. She explains that she used some of her peas to make soup (three times). In some variants, only one of the two partners keeps count in this manner.
This misc. type refers to a cycle of related anecdotes concerned with adultery. Usual-ly a husband catches his wife with her lover & exposes their affair.

Classifications: Child Unwittingly Betrays His Mother's Adultry
Variation Example: While her husband is away, a wife makes advances to one of his employees. This man draws a chalk circle on the floor & warns that he will “take revenge” on her if she crosses the line. The eager wife crosses the line & the employee has intercourse with her. When the husband returns, a child, who has seen what happened, warns him not to cross the line because if he does, the employee will do to him what he did to the mother, lie beside him & “fight”

Classifications: Hidden Lover Buys Freedom from Discoverer
Variation Example: A priest makes advances to a married woman. She pretends to agree to meet him, but tells her husband. At the rendezvous when the husband knocks on the door, the priest, who is already undressed, hides in a vat that contains tar (sirup). When he looks for a better place to hide, he finds himself in a vat of feathers. The man & his wife see him covered with tar & feathers & exhibit him as the devil (the man puts him in a crate & parades him around). Important people (people who come to the market) pay to see this “devil”. The priest often has to give all his wealth in order to ransom himself.

Classifications: Husband Carries Off Box Containing Hidden Lover
Variation Example: An adulterer (priest) who was surprised by his lover’s husband hides in a chest (which contains garbage, spoiled food, etc.). The husband (another lover, someone else) transports the chest together with its contents & exhibits it publicly (for a fee). The prisoner (who cries out from inside the chest) is set free after he pays a fine or a ransom (his friends or relatives pay it).

Classifications: Trickster Discovers Adultery; Fool Goes to Husband Instead of Lover
Variation Example: A traveler (student, soldier, etc.) asks for food & lodging, so a housewife gives him plain food & tells him to sleep in the haystack. He sees her (through a window) feasting in the company of her lover. When the husband comes home unexpectedly, he tells the traveler he would invite him in if he could offer him decent food. When the wife pretends that there is no food in the house, the traveler (with the help of a bird or magic implement) pretends to use magic to produce the (hidden) food leftover from the feast. He uses pretended magic a second time to raise the devil (actually the hidden lover) & chase him away. The lover & the wife or the host give the traveler a generous reward. Often the husband buys the magic object from him.
This type refers to a cycle of related anecdotes concerned with adultery. Usually a husband catches his wife with her lover & exposes their affair.

A man tries twice to catch his wife comitting adultery, but each time she manages to hide her lover. The third time, the husband burns down the house. The wife man ages (with the unwitting help of her husband) to rescue her lover.

A merchant (clergyman, monk, Jew) spends the night in a farmhouse, sharing a bed with the farmer & his wife. When the traveler wants to have intercourse with the wife, he pulls out a hair from the husband’s backside to find out if he is asleep. This happens several times, until finally the husband turns over & says, “I don’t mind what you do with my wife, but please don’t use my backside as a scoreboard!”In some variants the cheated person (teacher) discloses his identity by joining in the chorus when the two others (priest & nun) talk about the pleasure they have had the last night in a reciprocal song.

Classifications: Husband Meets the Lover in the Wife's Place
Variation Example: A husband suspects that while he is away at mass, his wife is having an affair with their children’s tutor. The husband wants to find out if this is true. One day when his wife is away & the husband is at home with the tutor, he invites the young man to a luxurious feast & offers him plenty of wine in order to loosen his tongue. The young man con-firms the husband’s suspicions, & is pardoned on the condition that he breaks off the relationship. Soon after, however, the merchant notices that the affair is still going on. In order to put an end to it, one morning he orders his wife to go to mass instead of him. As she leaves, she slams the door hard to signal to the young man that it was she & not her husband who went out. The young man wakes up late, believes that the husband has left, & goes to the wife’s bed, where he finds the merchant. The merchant insults him & beats him (castrates him).

Classifications: Husband Prepares to Castrate the Crucifix
Variation Example: A sculptor (icon-maker) & his wife want to put an end to the unwelcome attentions that the clergyman has been paying to the wife. She plans a meeting with the priest in the studio (in the church) & persuades him to take off his clothes (and paints his body). Surprised by the sudden appearance of the sculptor (icon-maker), the priest pretends to be Jesus standing before the cross among the sculptures (icons). The husband is about to castrate the figure (correct the sculpture) because the customer (bishop) supposedly does not like such a realistic representation. The priest runs away naked.
This misc. type comprises various tales dealing with adultery, most of which are not clearly described in the regional type catalogs.

Classifications: Flight of the Woman & her Lover from the Stable
Variation Example: When the husband is away from home a servant (guest, the husband himself) accidentally (from the roof) observes the housewife (his wife) with her lover (man, priest). When the servant is asked why he did so little work, he recites a verse that describes what he saw (he describes the event in the form of a story which he tells at dinner). The wife gives him money to stop telling the story. He concludes by saying that it was only a dream In some Estonian variants the tale continues: Because there are too many guests, the housewife cannot receive her lover. One guest pretends to be the housewife & refuses to let the lover come in, but instead castrates the lover through the window.

An unfaithful wife pretends to be ill & sends her husband for medicine. On his way the husband meets another man & has him carry him in a basket (sack, bundle of straw) back to his house, where his wife is entertaining her lover (the priest). They invite the man with the basket to eat with them. All three sing verses: first the wife, then the lover, then the guest. Often the husband in the basket sings the final verse. He comes out & a brawl ensues.

A clergyman (student) who wants to have a private meet-ing with a woman announces that a flood is coming. Her husband (carpenter, merchant, miller, farmer) tries to escape the flood in a tub tied up under the roof. While the adulterous couple are enjoying themselves, another lover comes & wants to take part or at least to have a kiss. The wife (clergyman) puts her (his) backside out the window & invites the lover to kiss it. He realizes he was tricked and, as if it were a second kiss, brands the backside of the clergyman with a hot iron. When the clergyman cries for water, the husband in the tub thinks the flood is coming. He cuts the rope, falls to the ground, & injures himself (dies).

(Modus Liebinc.) The wife of a merchant gives birth during her husband’s absence. When he comes home, she explains that she had become pregnant from eating snow (an icicle). The man pretends to accept the child as his son. When the boy grows up, the father takes him on a trip & sells him. Later he explains to his wife that the boy melted & dripped into the sea

Three months after the wedding, a young woman gives birth. Her husband thinks he has been cheated, but she (the priest) explains to him that he was married for three months, she was married for three months, & they were both together married for three months. This makes nine months in all, so he must recognize the child as his own. In some variants the father is told that his premature son will sur pass other children & become a good courier*.
A dying husband advises his wife to marry a man of the age of forty. She prefers to take two men of twenty.

Two traveling students spend the night in the house of a family with a beautiful wife & daughter. Everyone sleeps in the same room, with the youngest child in a cradle at the foot of the marriage bed. During the night one of the students sneaks into the bed of the daughter. When the mother leaves the room, the second student moves the cradle, so that when she comes back she mistakes his bed for hers & him for her husband. When the first student tries to go back to his own bed, he too is confused by the position of the cradle. He gets into bed with the father and, thinking that this is his friend, tells him what he has done. The father becomes angry & starts to beat the student. When the mother turns on the light, her lover puts the cradle back & moves his friend into their original bed. When she realizes what has happened, she tells her husband that they were visited by a demon. The students leave the following morning.

A lover boasts to his good friend that he has had a narrow escape from the husband of his mistress. The lover does not realize that this friend is in fact the husband, & tells him the particulars of his plans for the future (the time of their next appointment, etc.). Unbeknownst to the lover, the husband uses this information to try to surprise the guilty pair. Three times the couple are surprised by the husband, but the lover escapes by hiding behind a curtain, under the bed, in a cupboard, in a cistern, etc. Later (at a banquet) the lover boasts about his liason & adventures. He is accused of misconduct & asked to confess. He saves himself by saying it was all a dream.
This misc. type refers to a circle of related anecdotes dealing with a married couple each of which insists on being right. The wife in particular is blamed for being obstinate.
